Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They attend a local workshop on updated prescription guidelines to ensure proper patient counseling.
Story: I sat in the car outside the community center, my phone buzzing with another message from Mia. We’d argued three times this week about our budget, and she wanted to talk tonight—she said we couldn’t keep ignoring it. As her boyfriend, I knew I should go home, listen, and help us work through this. But inside, I clutched the workshop flyer, my name already on the sign-in sheet. The pharmacy had just updated our prescription guidelines, and my manager expected me to be on top of every change. If I missed this session, I’d fall behind, maybe even risk giving patients outdated advice. My chest tightened as I pictured Mia waiting, frustrated, while I sat in a room full of colleagues, my mind half on the lecture, half on her. I wanted to be the partner she needed, but I also couldn’t let my professional standards slip. The clock on the dashboard ticked closer to the workshop’s start time, and I stared at my phone, torn between two worlds that both demanded all of me.
